Centre Points in Factorial Design
• Let ത𝑟���𝐸��� is the average of the responses at all the factorial points and ത𝑟���𝐶 is the 
average of the responses at the centre points
• If ത𝑟���𝐸��� − ത𝑟���𝐶 is small, then the centre points lie near the plane created by the 
factorial points, and there is no significant curvature in the middle


--- Page 7 ---

--- Page 10 ---

Central Composite Design (CCD)
• CCD is one of the more popular designs for 2nd order response surface 
models. Another choice is Box-Behnken design.
 1. CCD has 2𝑖��� factorial runs, 2𝑖��� axial runs and 𝑖���𝐶 centre  runs
 2. Two parameters to be mentioned, distance 𝛼 of the axial points, 
number of  centre runs 𝑖���𝐶
3. The parameters are chosen based on rotatability, (ref sec 11.4.2)
    i.e. 𝑆��� ො𝑟��� 𝑟���
 should be same at all points 𝒙 placed at the same distance 
from the design centre.
4. Generally 𝛼 = 𝑖���𝐸���
1
4 and 𝑖���𝐶 = 3 to 5 is chosen


--- Page 11 ---

Central Composite Design (CCD)
• The experiment was conducted to find the optimal formulation of a two-
component admixture to improve the workabilty of cement grouts. The factors 
were the water-to-cement ratio, the percent of black liquor added, and the 
percent of SNF added. The response variable is plasticity. The left side of the 
table shows the coded factors 𝑟���1 − 𝑟���3. The axial points were chosen at ±1.68 
in coded units to make the design rotatable. The coded levels are found as 
(actual level − center value)/(half-range). For example, x2 = (BlackLiq: − 
0.150)/0.03.
(Source: Design and Analysis of Experiments with R,
John Lawson)


--- Page 12 ---

Central Composite Design (CCD)


--- Page 13 ---

Box Behnken Design
• CCD requires 5 levels (−𝛼, −1, 0, +1, +𝛼) for each factor, Box and Behnken 
(1960) developed some three level designs.
•  BBD allows estimation of the general quadratic model. 
• BBD consists of 22 factorials in each pair of factors 
   with all other factors held constant at their mid-level and a 
   few center points.
•  No Box-Behnken design exists for only two factors.
Source:
Design and Analysis of Experiments with R,
John Lawson


--- Page 14 ---

Box Behnken Design
• Box-Behnken designs have two advantages over CCDs. 
• BBD only require that factors be varied over three levels, reducing experimental cost for 
building prototypes.
• BBD usually (except for the 5-factor case) require less total runs than the CCD.
• A disadvantage of a Box-Behnken design compared to a CCD is that it cannot 
be built up in two steps beginning with a 2𝑖��� design.
• BBD should be used if the experimenter is reasonably sure that a linear model 
will not adequately represent the relationship between the factors and the 
response, and he or she wants to save a few runs.
• BBD is not rotatable, but close enough to being rotatable and having uniform 
precision for practical use. 


--- Page 15 ---

BBD Example
• As an example of a Box-Behnken design, consider the experiment performed
  by Anderson (2003). He experimented with a scale model trebuchet (medieval
missile launcher) that was issued to all engineering students at the South
Dakota School of Mines and Technology for hands-on experimentation. He
wanted to determine the settings that would allow him to toss an object a
given distance.


--- Page 16 ---

BBD Example


--- Page 17 ---

Response Surface Method (Ch11, DOE, Montgomery)
• Mathematical and statistical methods to analyze the influence of factors over 
the response variable and optimize the same
• 𝑟��� = 𝑐��� 𝑟���1, 𝑟���2 + 𝜖
• Expected response 𝐷��� 𝑟��� = 𝑐��� 𝑟���1, 𝑟���2 = 𝜂
• Surface representing 𝜂 is the response surface
Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery


--- Page 18 ---

RSM is sequential
• In RSM, if the initial conditions are far from optimal, we rapidly try to move 
towards optimal. A path of improvement towards general vicinity of optimum 
is followed.
• Once a region of optimal is found, more elaborate models, e.g. second order 
models are fitted.
• Similar to “hill climbing”
• Steepest ascent for maximization
• Steepest descent for minimization
Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery


--- Page 19 ---

Steepest Ascent in First Order Model


--- Page 20 ---

evaluation will by 𝑂 + 𝑖 ∗ Δ

     the point
5. Continue until the increase (or decrease in case of minimization) in response 
     stops.

Response Surface and Contour Plots


--- Page 25 ---

Canonical Form
• Canonical form of second order model
• For 2-3 factor models, it is easy to characterize
     response surface (maxima, minima or saddle 
     Point)
• For more variables, canonical analysis is helpful


--- Page 26 ---

Canonical Analysis
• Transform the model to a coordinate system with origin at 𝑋𝑟��� and rotate the 
axes to make them parallel to the principal axes of the response surface
• ො𝑟��� = ො𝑟���𝑟��� + 𝜆1𝑟���1
2 + ⋯ + 𝜆𝑖���𝑟���𝑖���
2
• 𝑟���𝑖s are the transformed variables and 𝜆𝑖s are eigenvalues of 𝑩.
• 𝜆𝑖s all positive:  𝑋𝑟��� is point of minimum response
• 𝜆𝑖s all negative:  𝑋𝑟��� is point of maximum response
• 𝜆𝑖s mixed signs:  𝑋𝑟��� is saddle point
• Surface is steepest in the 𝑟���𝑖 direction for which |𝜆𝑖| is greatest.


--- Page 27 ---

Multiple Response 
Optimization
Prof. Sayak Roychowdhury


--- Page 28 ---

Multiple Response Optimization
• When there are multiple responses (y’s) to be optimized
• If number of decision variables are limited to 2 or 3, overlay contour plot may 
be used
• Constrained optimization: where one response is set as objective while the 
values of others are constrained to desirable range.
• Desirability function approach: Proposed by Derringer and Suich (1980). 
Convert each response 𝑟���𝑖 to individual desirability values 𝑐���𝑖 such that 
   𝟎 ≤ 𝒅𝒊 ≤ 𝟎��� (0 means unacceptable and 1 means on target).
• Then the overall desirability is to be maximized:
• 𝐷 = 𝑐���1𝑐���2 … 𝑐���𝑚
1
𝑚  for 𝑖��� responses.


--- Page 29 ---

Multiple Response Example
• A chemical engineer is interested in determining the operating conditions that 
maximize the yield of a process (𝒙���𝟎���). 
• Two controllable variables influence process yield: reaction time (𝒙𝟎���) and 
reaction temperature (𝒙𝟎���). 
• The engineer is currently operating the process with a reaction time of 35 
minutes and a temperature of 155°F, result in yields of around 40%.
• It is unlikely that this region contains the optimum, she fits a first-order model 
and applies the method of steepest ascent.
• In the optimal region found using steepest ascent a CCD is created with 
experimental runs. 
• 2 additional responses, viscocity (𝑟���2) and molecular weight (𝑟���3) are also 
recorded.


--- Page 30 ---

Multiple Response Example
Source: Montgomery, D. C. (2017). Design and analysis of experiments. John wiley 
& sons.

Constrained Optimization
• When there are more than 3 design variables, overlaying contour plots 
becomes cumbersome, as the contour plot is two dimensional, and 𝑖��� − 2 of 
the design variables must be held constant to construct the graph. 
• A popular approach is to formulate and solve the problem as a constrained 
optimization problem.

Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery


--- Page 36 ---

Experimental Designs for Fitting Response Surface
• According to “Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery”, the following 
properties are considered important for experimental designs meant for response 
surface optimization
1.
Reasonable spread of datapoints in the region of interest
2.
Allows model adequacy, including lack of fit to be investigated
3.
Allows experiments to be performed in blocks
4.
Allows design of higher order to be performed sequentially
5.
Provides an internal estimate of error
6.
Precise estimates of model coefficients
7.
Reasonable robustness against outliers and missing values
8.
Good profile of prediction variance
9.
Does not require a large number of runs
10. Does not require too many levels of each factor
11. Simplicity of calculation of model parameters
12. Rotatability: For 2nd order design, variance of the predicted response should be same at all 
points at the same distance from the design centre.

paragraphs.text: •  The experiment was conducted to find the optimal formulation of a two-

component admixture to improve the workabilty of cement grouts. The factors  were the water-to-cement ratio, the percent of black liquor added, and the  percent of SNF added. The response variable is plasticity. The left side of the  table shows the coded factors  𝑟�1 − 𝑟�3 . The axial points were chosen at  ±1.68   in coded units to make the design rotatable. The coded levels are found as  (actual level − center value)/(half-range). For example, x2 = (BlackLiq: −  0.150)/0.03.
( Source: Design and Analysis of Experiments with R, John Lawson)

were the water-to-cement ratio, the percent of black liquor added, and the 
percent of SNF added. The response variable is plasticity. The left side of the

in coded units to make the design rotatable. The coded levels are found as 
(actual level − center value)/(half-range). For example, x2 = (BlackLiq: −

paragraphs.text: •  CCD requires 5 levels  (−𝛼, −1, 0, +1, +𝛼)  for each factor, Box and Behnken

•   BBD allows estimation of the general quadratic model.  •  BBD consists of  2 2  factorials in each pair of factors     with all other factors held constant at their mid-level and a     few center points. •   No Box-Behnken design exists for only two factors.
Design and Analysis of Experiments with R,

pages.full_text:
Box Behnken Design
• CCD requires 5 levels (−𝛼, −1, 0, +1, +𝛼) for each factor, Box and Behnken 
(1960) developed some three level designs.
•  BBD allows estimation of the general quadratic model. 
• BBD consists of 22 factorials in each pair of factors 
   with all other factors held constant at their mid-level and a 
   few center points.
•  No Box-Behnken design exists for only two factors.
Source:
Design and Analysis of Experiments with R,
John Lawson

paragraphs.text: •  Box-Behnken designs have two advantages over CCDs.
•  BBD only require that factors be varied over three levels, reducing experimental cost for
•  BBD usually (except for the 5-factor case) require less total runs than the CCD.
•  A disadvantage of a Box-Behnken design compared to a CCD is that it cannot
be built up in two steps beginning with a  2 𝑖�  design.
•  BBD should be used if the experimenter is reasonably sure that a linear model
will not adequately represent the relationship between the factors and the  response, and he or she wants to save a few runs.
•  BBD is not rotatable, but close enough to being rotatable and having uniform

pages.full_text:
Box Behnken Design
• Box-Behnken designs have two advantages over CCDs. 
• BBD only require that factors be varied over three levels, reducing experimental cost for 
building prototypes.
• BBD usually (except for the 5-factor case) require less total runs than the CCD.
• A disadvantage of a Box-Behnken design compared to a CCD is that it cannot 
be built up in two steps beginning with a 2𝑖��� design.
• BBD should be used if the experimenter is reasonably sure that a linear model 
will not adequately represent the relationship between the factors and the 
response, and he or she wants to save a few runs.
• BBD is not rotatable, but close enough to being rotatable and having uniform 
precision for practical use.

paragraphs.text: •  As an example of a Box-Behnken design, consider the experiment performed   by Anderson (2003). He experimented with a scale model trebuchet (medieval missile launcher) that was issued to all engineering students at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology for hands-on experimentation. He wanted to determine the settings that would allow him to toss an object a given distance.

pages.full_text:
BBD Example
• As an example of a Box-Behnken design, consider the experiment performed
  by Anderson (2003). He experimented with a scale model trebuchet (medieval
missile launcher) that was issued to all engineering students at the South
Dakota School of Mines and Technology for hands-on experimentation. He
wanted to determine the settings that would allow him to toss an object a
given distance.

paragraphs.text: •  In RSM, if the initial conditions are far from optimal, we rapidly try to move
towards optimal. A path of improvement towards general vicinity of optimum  is followed.
•  Once a region of optimal is found, more elaborate models, e.g. second order
•  Similar to “hill climbing” •  Steepest ascent for maximization •  Steepest descent for minimization
Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery

pages.full_text:
RSM is sequential
• In RSM, if the initial conditions are far from optimal, we rapidly try to move 
towards optimal. A path of improvement towards general vicinity of optimum 
is followed.
• Once a region of optimal is found, more elaborate models, e.g. second order 
models are fitted.
• Similar to “hill climbing”
• Steepest ascent for maximization
• Steepest descent for minimization
Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery

•  The engineer is currently operating the process with a reaction time of 35
minutes and a temperature of 155°F, result in yields of around 40%.

and applies the method of steepest ascent.
•  In the optimal region found using steepest ascent a CCD is created with

pages.full_text:
Multiple Response Example
• A chemical engineer is interested in determining the operating conditions that 
maximize the yield of a process (𝒙���𝟎���). 
• Two controllable variables influence process yield: reaction time (𝒙𝟎���) and 
reaction temperature (𝒙𝟎���). 
• The engineer is currently operating the process with a reaction time of 35 
minutes and a temperature of 155°F, result in yields of around 40%.
• It is unlikely that this region contains the optimum, she fits a first-order model 
and applies the method of steepest ascent.
• In the optimal region found using steepest ascent a CCD is created with 
experimental runs. 
• 2 additional responses, viscocity (𝑟���2) and molecular weight (𝑟���3) are also 
recorded.

paragraphs.text: Experimental Designs for Fitting Response Surface
•  According to “Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery”, the following
properties are considered important for experimental designs meant for response  surface optimization
1. Reasonable spread of datapoints in the region of interest
2. Allows model adequacy, including lack of fit to be investigated
3. Allows experiments to be performed in blocks
4. Allows design of higher order to be performed sequentially
5. Provides an internal estimate of error
7. Reasonable robustness against outliers and missing values
9. Does not require a large number of runs

10. Does not require too many levels of each factor 11. Simplicity of calculation of model parameters 12. Rotatability: For 2 nd  order design, variance of the predicted response should be same at all
points at the same distance from the design centre.

pages.full_text:
Experimental Designs for Fitting Response Surface
• According to “Design and Analysis of Experiment, D.C. Montgomery”, the following 
properties are considered important for experimental designs meant for response 
surface optimization
1.
Reasonable spread of datapoints in the region of interest
2.
Allows model adequacy, including lack of fit to be investigated
3.
Allows experiments to be performed in blocks
4.
Allows design of higher order to be performed sequentially
5.
Provides an internal estimate of error
6.
Precise estimates of model coefficients
7.
Reasonable robustness against outliers and missing values
8.
Good profile of prediction variance
9.
Does not require a large number of runs
10. Does not require too many levels of each factor
11. Simplicity of calculation of model parameters
12. Rotatability: For 2nd order design, variance of the predicted response should be same at all 
points at the same distance from the design centre.
